title: How did people translate ancient texts? - Quora

response.answer_text: Even if the native speakers have died out, there will be intermediate forms to work from. An ancient language does not exist in total isolation (except possibly Basque!). So Champollion was able to translate ancient hieroglyphics despite the fact that nobody spoke ancient Egyptian, because he had the Rosetta Stone -- a trilingual document in two forms of Egyptian and ancient Greek. He also was aware that Coptic, the liturgical language of the Egyptian Christian Church, was descended from ancient Egyptian. So there were clues in other languages that he could work form. There do remain a few languages that we've never translated because we haven't found enough connections to any that we know. Linear A is one.

Various ways.  Egyptian hieroglyphs were cracked using the Rosetta Stone, plus a realisation that Coptic was a descendant of their original language.  (See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs.)  Similar things for other empires. Linear B was cracked using place-names, and the realisation that it was archaic Greek.  (See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_B). Some scripts remain uncracked.  Linear A read with the sound values of Linear B comes out as gibberish.  Possibly an unknown language, but also these might have been ideograms.  The symbols used by the Indus Valley Civilization remain an enigma and it's not certain it was ever a full writing system.

Constantinople only fell to the Ottomans in 1453, so up to that point an Islamic scholar could probably just wondered into the Greek speaking / writing Byzantine empire and ask for someone to translate one of the books they'd captured. Or asked any of the Greeks they'd enslaved during the Islamic conquest. There were initially, at least, Jewish, Coptic, Orthodox, Roman Catholic .... scholars in places such as Baghdad, who could also offer translations.

The Arabic translations were not that accurate: that is why William of Moerbeke did his own translations from Greek to Latin; the scholars of the High Middle Ages used these translations instead to make their breakthroughs in the understanding of Aristotle. Many of the Arab translations weren't even straight translation from Greek to Arabic: they translated the Syriac version instead. This is another reason why Europe learned quickly to prefer Moerbeke's translations. Syriac is closely related to Arabic and Hebrew, and was still widely spoken. It is still spoken today, but not widely anymore.

The Arabs in the middle ages had easy access to Greek scholarship via the Byzantine Empire's scholars and other Greek speaking peoples in the area. This book will help answer your question using the Bible as a good example of the scholarship required:Misquoting Jesus: The Story Behind Who Changed the Bible and Why by Bart D. Ehrman
